title: 46 Mott
description: 46 Mott is a Cantonese-style bakery best known to the Chinatown community for its work to provide free meals to those in need during the COVID crisis. 46 Mott has no formal menu. Instead, customers come into this quintessential bakery to explore the day’s offerings: new ingredients that are seasonal, foods that are trending, and more.

title: Tonii’s Fresh Rice Noodle
description: Opened in October 2019, Tonii’s specializes in the Cantonese dim sum classic cheung-fun, otherwise known as rice noodle rolls. The small eatery on Bayard Street offers a wide variety of Hong Kong-style breakfast foods that make for a quintessential element of the Chinatown experience.

title: Taiwan Bear House
description: Opened in October 2019, Tonii’s specializes in the Cantonese dim sum classic cheung-fun, otherwise known as rice noodle rolls. The small eatery on Bayard Street offers a wide variety of Hong Kong-style breakfast foods that make for a quintessential element of the Chinatown experience.

title: Winnie's Bar
description: Through the years, the bar has garnered a number of different reputations (gangster bar, bridge and tunnel bar, hipster bar, NYU bar), but one thing about Winnie’s has never changed: people return to Winnie’s time and time again for a laid-back, no-frills experience because they know they’ll all be treated and welcomed the same.

title: Fong On
description: Since 1933, the Eng family has been providing the neighborhood and beyond with Toisanese staples including tofu, soy milk, noodles, and rice cake. For three generations, Fong Inn Too was the pinnacle of Old Chinatown.

title: Kopitiam
description: Opened in October 2019, Tonii’s specializes in the Cantonese dim sum classic cheung-fun, otherwise known as rice noodle rolls. The small eatery on Bayard Street offers a wide variety of Hong Kong-style breakfast foods that make for a quintessential element of the Chinatown experience.

title: Uncle Lou
description: Uncle Lou’s menu is divided into standard categories: Dim sum, noodle soup, beef, chicken, seafood and so on. The “lo wah kiu favorites” column “takes grandparents back to the Cantonese villages in Toisan, Sunwui, Enping, and Hoiping.”

title: Po Wing Hong
description: Established in 1980, Po Wing Hong Food Market began as a modest store located on Hester Street in the heart of New York City’s Chinatown. Reflecting the owners’ Hong Kong origins, our store offers many products common in Cantonese cuisine. As people from the Guangdong region of China are known for cooking daily nourishing and restorative soups, our store maintains a wide range of quality herbs and soup ingredients.
